official-title.#text: Commemorating the 100th Anniversary of the World War I Christmas Truce of 1914.

sponsor.#tail: submitted the following resolution; which was referred to the

text.#text: honors the 100th Anniversary of the World War I Christmas Truce of 1914;
recognizes the Christmas Truce’s symbol of the triumph of the human spirit over adversity; and

commemorates the World War I Christmas Truce of 1914 and its legacy as a message of future peace
			 and unity between all nations.

Whereas the cries and moans of the injured and dying in no man’s land could be heard throughout the
			 Western Front, and many of the dead had been lying unburied;

Whereas, on December 7, 1914, Pope Benedict XV suggested a temporary hiatus of the war for the
			 celebration of Christmas;
Whereas despite this proposal, the warring countries refused to create any official cease-fire;

quote.#text: On Christmas Eve the firing practically ceased. …

text.#text:
Whereas another letter from Private Cunningham, of the 5th Scottish Rifles, to his friend Mr. James
			 D Gray, in Carluke, Scotland, also reveals in more detail how such truces
			 came about:

Whereas, on Christmas Day, the soldiers of opposing forces emerged from their trenches and declared
			 their own unofficial truce, and shook hands with their enemies;

Whereas worldwide celebrations are expected to take place, including the unveiling of a sculpture
			 by Andy Edwards in Liverpool capturing the 1914 Christmas Day football
			 match; and

Whereas the lessons of this event are that the light of human empathy can dispel the darkness of
			 despair, the possibility for future peace can still exist when at war with
			 other nations, and that behind the clashing of weapons and trenches of
			 indifference humanity essentially endures: Now, therefore, be it

{http://purl.org/dc/elements/1.1/}title.#text: 113 HRES 781 IH: Commemorating the 100th Anniversary of the World War I Christmas Truce of 1914.
